general.title: Welcome to the Epeios project WEB site
general.abstract: The Epeios project, the most simple and effective way to develop software.
general.keywords: Epeios, software engineering, software, free software, free, linux, windows, C++, unix, open source, open software, GNU, GPL, FSF
general.author: $AUTHOR$

section.para: This is the official web site of the Epeios project, which goal is to find the most simple and effective way to develop software.
See licenses statement for the conditions of use of the Epeios libraries and software.

All document available on this web site are written by people for which English isn't the native language ; some people are working to correct the English errors, so, please, DON'T send any report about this errors.
Other remarks/questions/suggestions are welcome and can be send to Claude L. Simon.

list.item: About the Epeios project : more about the Epeios project.
General documentation: description of the underlying concepts on which the Epeios project is based.

section.para: This site is entirely made using XML/XSL and some Epeios tools. The XSLT transformation is made using Sablotron. The project is hosted by Savannah.

I, Claude L. Simon, live in France and I am the webmaster of this site, the maintainer of the Epeios project and the developer of all the software and libraries. I make all this during my spare time, essentially writing and maintaining the libraries in order to keep them of high quality. So, I have only very few time to write the documentation which would make it easy for other to use the more then 100 available Epeios libraries.
I'm currently looking for a job, in France, near Strasbourg (Alsace/Bas-Rhin). You will find here a french version of my CV.

general.title: Licenses of the Epeios libraries and software
general.abstract: Condition of use of the the Epeios libraries and software.
general.author: $AUTHOR$

section.para: By default, all the Epeios software and libraries are released under GNU General Public License. Actually, I plan to release all coming Epeios software and libraries under this license too. However, if you want to use the Epeios software or libraries, but under conditions which are not allowed by the GNU GPL, write me your request. As the one and only who has written all the Epeios software and libraries, I can possibly authorize you to use them under other conditions as those specified by the GNU GPL.

general.title: The Epeios libraries
general.abstract: Homepage of the Epeios libraries
general.author: $AUTHOR$

section.para: Along with the core libraries of the Epeios libraries, you will find here libraries which are dedicated to special tasks. There are all part of the Epeios project, because they follow the Epeios standards and they are based on the Epeios core libraries. To learn more about the Epeios project, follow this link.

list.item: Core libraries : the core libraries of the Epeios project. They are not dedicated to special tasks, but all the other libraries are based on them.
EXML libraries : libraries dedicated to the handling of data in XML format.
EMTH libraries : libraries dedicated to mathematical libraries, for high-precision calculations.
EBKD libraries : libraries dedicated to backend handling.
ECGI libraries : libraries dedicated to CGIs.
ETMC libraries : libraries dedicated to timecodes.
EJAVA libraries : JAVA implementation of the Epeios frontend/backend protocol.

general.title: Core libraries homepage
general.abstract: The Epeios core libraries, for general purposes.
general.author: $AUTHOR$

section.para: See licenses statement for the conditions of use of this libraries.
You will find here all that concern the Epeios core libraries. To learn more about the Epeios project, follow this link.

This libraries are not dedicated to special tasks, but covers what you usually need to develop software or other libraries. This libraries, therefore, deal with memory management, error handling, sockets, multitasking, semaphores, pipes, shared memory, lists, stacks, queues, indexes, ...

list.item: Quickdoc : to quickly find the description of the classes/methods/functions.
User documentation : how to use the libraries.

general.title: Epeios software homepage.
general.abstract: The homepage of the Epeios software.
general.author: $AUTHOR$

section.para: You will find here some Epeios software, based on Epeios libraries. Go to the Epeios project homepage for more about this libraries.
Under UNIX (at least under GNU/Linux), you obtain the binary of the software by decompressing the given source files and launching make.

As part of the Epeios project, all the software work under Windows too. You have to compile it, but, because Windows compiler don't all work the same way, as far as I know, there is no standard procedure to doing that.
The Makefiles are designed for GNU Make (check here for miscelleanous port). To work, the enviroment variable EPEIOS_OS, must be set to linux under GNU/Linux and windows under Windows.

Under GNU/Linux, the software were tested with GNU GCC V$GCC_VERSION$. Under Windows, BC++ can be used, but, due the limitation of the length of a command line under some Windows version, some Makefile don't work properly on linking. Both compiler are available for free.

The packages found under the download section of each software didn't contain the software version in its name as usual, but the date of its release. This is due to the particular way the Epeios software are made.

The main source of an Epeios software is mostly contituted with calls to libraries. This libraries are the core of the software, but they are generally used by more that one software, and it doesn't take sens to modify the version number of each software which use a given library when this library change.

The main source of two releases of a software can so have the same version number, but are different because the libraries which are used changed. This is why the --version command of a software displays both main source version and version of the libraries.

list.item: mll2html : GNU program, written for the FSF, which which reformats a pure ASCII mailinglists file to a HTML formated mailinglists file.
reveal : replaces tags in a file by text or file content.
tmcde : interactive software for timecode calculation.
getbkdapi : software to generate the API of an Epeios backend.

general.title: TMCDE software homepage.
general.abstract: The timecode manager software (TMCDE) from the Epeios project.
general.author: $AUTHOR$

section.para: All the pieces of this software are placed under GNU General Public License.
You will find here all that concern the Epeios timecode manager software. To learn more about the Epeios project, follow this link.

This software allows calculation with timecodes (usually expressed in hours, minutes, second and frames). This software, like all interactive Epeios software, is divided in 2 parts. One is the backend, which is the treatment part of the software, and the other is the frontend, which is the user interface.
Actually, the backend is a daemon, which is multitasking and multi user. But, in the future, this backend would also be available as a dynamic library, for using in a monotasking, mono user context.
There is only one frontend actually available, and this is the WEB one. This frontend works only with the daemon version of the backend. It acts like a CGI, so you need an http server, like Apache.
A Java-based frontend is also planed, which would be usable with the yet available backend daemon, and with the comming dynamic library version of the daemon.

list.item: Backend : the backend, common to all frontend.

general.title: TMCDE software demonstration page.
general.abstract: The timecode manager software (TMCDE) from the Epeios project.
general.author: $AUTHOR$

section.para:
You will find here two links to test the TMCDE software with the WEB interface. The difference between the 2 links is the appearance of the duration list. The software is 'skinnable' by providing several XSL files.
With links for the duration list.
With a select box for the duration list.
.

general.title: GNU 'mll2html' software homepage.
general.abstract: The homepage of the GNU 'mll2html' software from the Epeios project.
general.keywords: Epeios, GNU, FSF, software, mll2html, homepage
general.author: $AUTHOR$

section.para: The mll2html software was written for the FSF. It's a GNU program which reformats a mailinglists text file (like this) to a HTML mailinglists file (like this).
Go to Epeios software main page to know how to obtain the binary.

general.title: GNU 'mll2html' software example of use.
general.abstract: An example of use of the GNU 'mll2html' software from the Epeios project.
general.keywords: Epeios, GNU, FSF, software, mll2html, example
general.author: $AUTHOR$

section.para: The mll2html package comes with 2 files : mailinglists.txt and templates.html. The mailinglists.txt is a text file containing the descriptions of mailing lists. The templates.html is a file containing tags (letters between two $$), which are replaced in the resulting file with the content of the mailinglists.txt file formatted in HTML.

The following command mll2html mailinglists.txt template.html result.html generates a file named result.html which is based on templates.html with tags replaced by the content of mailinglists.txt formatted in HTML.

general.title: 'reveal' software homepage.
general.abstract: The homepage of the 'reveal' software from the Epeios project.
general.author: $AUTHOR$

section.para: The reveal software replaces tags in a file by text or file content. Go to Epeios software main page to know how to obtain the binary.

general.title: 'reveal' software example of use.
general.abstract: An example of use of the 'reveal' software from the Epeios project.
general.author: $AUTHOR$

section.para: The reveal package comes with 5 files. 1 source file (source.txt), 2 tag description files (single.crp and multi.crp), and 3 example files (file1.txt, file2.txt and file3.txt).

To test the single mode of reveal, launch reveal single.crp source.txt single.txt. This will parse source.txt and write it into single.txt which each tag replaced according with the content of single.crp.

The test the multi mode, launch reveal multi.crp source.txt multi.txt. This will parse source.txt and write it into multi.txt which each tag replaced according with the content of each line of single.crp. The content of source.txt is write as many as there are lines describing the content of the tags in multi.crp.

general.title: 'getbkdapi' software homepage.
general.abstract: The homepage of the 'getbkdapi' software from the Epeios project.
general.author: $AUTHOR$

section.para: The getbkdapi connects to an Epeios backend (i.e. which uses the EBKD libraries), and generates, in XML format, the description of all the objects and their methods which are handled by this backend. With the appropriate XSL file, an API for this backend can be generated in all langages. Actually, the XSL file is available for C++ and JAVA. Go to Epeios software main page to know how to obtain the binary.

general.title: 'getbkdapi' software example of use.
general.abstract: An example of use of the 'getbkdapi' software from the Epeios project.
general.author: $AUTHOR$

section.para: Click here to see the content of the file which is generated by the getbkdapi software for the tmcde backend, as you can try by yourself, if you are connected to internet, by launching getbkdapi cgi.epeios.org:1025.
When you apply this file to the XML file, you obtain a C++ header file like this, which is used for the tmcde WEB frontend .

general.title: Curriculum vitae.
general.abstract: CV of SIMON Claude
general.author: $AUTHOR$

section.para:
I'm currently looking for a job, in France, near Strasbourg (Alsace/Bas-Rhin). There is a french version of my CV in miscellaneous formats :
cv.pdf : Acrobat format.
cv.doc : WinWord format.
